messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Dogs live in groups. They learn something. People often give food to small, cute dogs. So, these small dogs go to ask for food. They get food for all the group.

Some dogs also learn to use the city trains. They go from one area to another area. Scientists do not know one thing. How do dogs know when to leave the train?

One idea is this: Dogs have a very good way to smell. They learn to know the smells of their favourite places. Another idea is this: They learn the names of stations. They hear the names when people speak on the train.

So, people on the train are now used to seeing dogs. Locals often do not see them.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5934 is significantly below the required 0.75. This indicates a critical loss of the original text's core message and nuance. The writer's output oversimplifies key concepts, diluting the original meaning. For example: 1. The phrase 'They learn something' is excessively vague and fails to convey the specific learning point that 'humans are more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs'. This removes the strategic element of the dogs' behavior. 2. The original concept of dogs being 'sent to beg for food' due to human preference is reduced to 'these small dogs go to ask for food', losing the nuance of a deliberate strategy within the pack. 3. The causal relationship 'metro passengers have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed by locals' is broken into two separate, less connected statements: 'people on the train are now used to seeing dogs. Locals often do not see them.' This diminishes the logical flow and the consequence of human familiarity. Suggestion: Rephrase sentences to retain the specific details of what the dogs learn and why they act, and preserve the causal connections between events. Avoid overly generic phrases like 'learn something'.

Some dogs also learn to use the city trains. They go from one area to another area. Scientists do not know one thing. How do dogs know when to get off the train?

One idea is this: Dogs have a very good smell. They learn the smells of their favourite places. Another idea is this: They learn the names of stations. They hear the names when people speak on the train.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6091 is significantly below the required 0.75. Your text fails to fully capture the nuanced meaning of the original. The original text describes a strategic, learned behavior where packs send 'smaller, cuter dogs' to 'beg for food for the whole pack' because humans are 'more likely to give food' to them. Your version, 'So, the group sends these small dogs. They ask for food for all the group,' simplifies this to the point of losing the strategic element and the 'more likely' aspect of human behavior that drives the dogs' actions. This diminishes the core message of the pack's calculated exploitation of human empathy. Additionally, the phrase 'travel largely unnoticed by locals' in the original implies a state of being ignored due to familiarity, whereas your 'So, locals often do not see them' is a more literal and less nuanced interpretation, losing the subtle implication of indifference despite presence. Suggestion: Rephrase the first and last sentences to more accurately convey the strategic and nuanced meanings of the original text, ensuring the 'why' behind the dogs' actions and the 'how' of their unnoticed travel are preserved.

Some dogs also learn to use the city trains. They go from one area to another area. Scientists do not know one thing. How do dogs know when to get off the train?

One idea is this: Dogs have a very good smell. They learn the smells of their favourite places. Another idea is this: They learn the names of stations. They hear the names when people speak on the train.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5964 is significantly below the required 0.75, indicating a substantial loss of the original text's core message and nuance. While the BERTScore is acceptable, the deeper meaning has been compromised. Specific deviations include: 1. The phrase 'more likely to give food' in the original, which implies a strategic understanding by the dogs, is simplified to 'give more food'. This loses the nuance of probability and the dogs' learned strategy. 2. The emphasis conveyed by 'even learnt' in the original, highlighting the surprising nature of the dogs' ability to use the metro, is reduced to 'also learn', diminishing the impact. 3. The original clearly states the dogs are unnoticed by the local population due to their common presence. Suggestion: Rephrase to restore the strategic implication of 'more likely'. Reintroduce the emphasis of 'even learnt'. Clarify the final sentence to explicitly state that the dogs are unnoticed by locals.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Dogs live in groups. They learn that people often give food to small, cute dogs. So, the group sends these dogs. They ask for food for all the group.

Some dogs are very clever. They also learn to use the city trains. They go from one area to another area. Scientists do not know one thing. How do dogs know when to get off the train?

One idea is this: Dogs have a very good smell. They learn the smells of their favourite places. Another idea is this: They learn the names of stations. They hear the names when people speak on the train.

People on the train are now used to seeing dogs. So, locals do not notice the dogs.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5996 is significantly below the required 0.75. This indicates a substantial loss of the original text's core message and nuance, despite maintaining factual accuracy. The simplification was too aggressive, removing critical details and specific meanings. Specific deviations include: 1. The phrase 'more likely to give food' was reduced to 'often give food', losing the comparative aspect. 2. 'Beg for food' was simplified to 'ask for food', which diminishes the specific nature of the dogs' action. 3. 'Even learnt' implying a surprising skill was replaced by 'are very clever', which is an interpretation rather than a direct preservation of the original meaning. 4. 'Metro system' and 'territory' were generalized to 'city trains' and 'area', losing specificity. 5. 'Excellent sense of smell' was weakened to 'very good smell'. 6. 'Recognise the scents of their favourite destinations' was simplified to 'learn the smells of their favourite places', losing the active verb 'recognise' and the specific term 'destinations'. 7. 'Announcements' was vaguely rephrased as 'when people speak on the train', losing the specific context of public address. 8. 'Largely unnoticed' was changed to 'do not notice', removing the nuance of 'mostly' and making it absolute. These cumulative changes resulted in a diluted message. Suggestion: Reintroduce key verbs and specific nouns that convey the original meaning more accurately while remaining within A2 vocabulary. Focus on preserving the nuance of actions and descriptions.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Dogs live in groups. They learn that people give more food to small, cute dogs. So, the group sends these dogs to beg for food for all the group.

Some dogs learn a surprising thing. They learn to use the city's metro system. They go from one part of their own area to another. Scientists do not know one thing: How do dogs know when to get off the train?

One idea is this: Dogs have a very good sense of smell. They learn to know the smells of their favourite places. Another idea is this: They learn the names of stations. They hear the names from the train announcements.

People on the train are now used to seeing dogs. So, locals mostly do not notice the dogs.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6476 is too low, falling below the required 0.75. While the text preserves many keywords, the simplification of sentence structures and subtle changes in phrasing have altered the core meaning and nuance of the original text. The BERTScore of 0.9165 indicates good lexical fidelity, but this is insufficient when the overall meaning is compromised.

*   The phrase 'Some dogs learn a surprising thing' adds an interpretive element not present in the original's 'Some dogs have even learnt', which conveyed unexpectedness through 'even' rather than an explicit statement of surprise. This is an addition to the meaning.
*   The original's 'Scientists are not sure how the dogs know' was simplified to 'Scientists do not know one thing: How do dogs know'. The addition of 'one thing' changes the nuance from general uncertainty to a specific, singular unknown, which is a subtle but significant shift in meaning.
*   The original's 'One idea is that they use...' and 'Another possibility is that they have learnt...' use 'that' clauses to introduce ideas. Your version uses 'One idea is this:' and 'Another idea is this:', which, while simpler, breaks the direct semantic connection of the original's structure, impacting meaning fidelity.
*   The original's 'have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed' conveys a cause-and-effect relationship and a degree of being unnoticed. Your version 'People on the train are now used to seeing dogs. So, locals mostly do not notice the dogs' simplifies this to two separate statements, losing the direct causal link and the full extent of 'largely unnoticed'.

Suggestion: Re-evaluate how complex ideas and nuances are simplified. Ensure that structural changes do not inadvertently alter the core message or the relationships between ideas. Focus on preserving the original's specific meaning, even when simplifying vocabulary and grammar. Do not add interpretive elements or change the nuance of uncertainty.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6338 is too low, falling significantly below the required 0.75. The simplification has removed too much nuance and detail, leading to a loss of the original message's depth and specific meaning. The text is factually correct, but the essence of the original message is diluted. Specific deviations include: The original text emphasizes the surprising nature of dogs using the metro system with 'Some dogs have even learnt...', which is lost in the simplified 'Some dogs learn...'. The original's explanatory structure 'One idea is that they use...' and 'Another possibility is that they have learnt...' is reduced to abrupt 'One idea: Dogs have...' and 'Another idea: They learn...', which diminishes the explanatory flow. The nuance of 'largely unnoticed' is lost by the absolute 'do not notice'. Suggestion: Re-evaluate the simplification strategy. Ensure that key causal relationships, surprising elements, and the specific reasons for actions are retained, even with simpler vocabulary and grammar. Do not sacrifice the core message for simplicity. For example, the connection between 'smaller, cuter dogs' and 'being sent to beg' needs to be clearer. The 'even' for the metro system should be subtly conveyed.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Dogs live in groups. They learn that people give more food to small dogs. Small dogs look nice. So, the group sends these small dogs to beg for food. The food is for all the group.

Some dogs even learn to use the city's metro system. They go from one part of their area to another. Scientists do not know how dogs know when to get off the train.

One idea is this: Dogs have a very good sense of smell. They learn to know the smells of their favourite places. Another idea is this: They learn the names of stations. They hear the names from the train announcements.

People on the train see dogs often now. So, locals mostly do not notice the dogs.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6227 is significantly below the required 0.75. This indicates a substantial loss of the original text's core meaning and nuance, despite lexical simplification. Specific issues include: 1. The original phrase 'humans are more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs' implies a learned strategy by the dogs based on human preference. Your version 'people give more food to small dogs. Small dogs look nice.' simplifies this to a mere observation, losing the strategic 'more likely' aspect. 2. The final sentence 'metro passengers have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed by locals' conveys a strong degree of familiarity and the direct consequence of being unnoticed. Your version 'People on the train see dogs often now. So, locals mostly do not notice the dogs.' weakens this cause-and-effect and the intensity of the familiarity. The 'so...that' structure, while B1, conveys a specific meaning that must be preserved in an A2-appropriate manner. Suggestion: Rephrase the first sentence to clearly state that dogs learn people prefer small, nice-looking dogs for food. Suggestion: Rephrase the final sentence to more strongly link the high frequency of seeing dogs with the result of them being unnoticed, using A2 structures that convey a stronger connection than a simple 'So'.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Dogs live in groups. They learn that people like small, nice dogs. People give more food to these dogs. So, the group sends these small dogs to beg for food. The food is for all the group.

Some dogs even learn to use the city's metro system. They go from one part of their area to another. Scientists do not know how dogs know when to get off the train.

One idea is this: Dogs have a very good sense of smell. They learn to know the smells of their favourite places. Another idea is this: They learn the names of stations. They hear the names from the train announcements.

People on the train see dogs very often now. They are used to seeing them. So, locals do not notice the dogs.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6592 is below the required 0.75. This indicates a significant loss of the original text's core message and nuanced meaning. The text fails to convey the full scope of the original's information. 

*   The original text's specific detail that humans are 'more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs' is simplified to 'people like small, nice dogs. People give more food to these dogs.' The nuance of 'cuter' and the direct causal link for human preference is diminished. 
*   The complex causal structure 'metro passengers have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed by locals' is broken into disconnected sentences: 'People on the train see dogs very often now. They are used to seeing them. So, locals do not notice the dogs.' This simplification loses the direct cause-and-effect relationship and the specific meaning of 'largely unnoticed'. 
*   The original's use of 'recognise the scents' and 'recognise the names' implies a specific cognitive ability. The simplified 'learn to know the smells' and 'learn the names' is a weaker, less precise description of this ability, contributing to meaning loss. 
*   The overall simplification of complex sentences into very short, declarative sentences, while aiming for A2, has inadvertently fragmented the logical flow and the subtle connections between ideas present in the original, leading to a diminished overall meaning. 

Suggestion: Rephrase sentences to maintain the causal relationships and specific details, even with simpler vocabulary. Ensure that the core reasons and consequences are clearly linked.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Dogs live in groups. They learn that people often give food to small, cute dogs. So, the group sends these dogs to beg for food for everyone.

Some dogs learn to use the city metro. They go from one area to another area. Scientists do not know how dogs get off the train at the right time.

One idea is this: Dogs have a very good smell. They learn to recognise the smells of their favourite places. Another idea is this: They learn to recognise station names. They hear these names in train announcements.

People on the metro see dogs often now. They are used to seeing them. So, locals do not often notice the dogs.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6597 is too low, falling below the required 0.75. Your text loses important nuances and the full impact of the original message. Specific issues include: The phrase 'more likely to give food' was simplified to 'often give food', which loses the comparative aspect of the original. The emphasis of 'even learnt' was lost by simplifying to 'learn', removing the sense of surprise or unexpected skill. 'Excellent sense of smell' was reduced to 'very good smell', diminishing the strength of the dogs' ability. 'Scents of their favourite destinations' was simplified to 'smells of their favourite places', losing the specific and slightly more refined connotation of 'scents' and the precise term 'destinations'. 'Another possibility' was changed to 'Another idea', which slightly alters the nature of the proposed explanation. The complex causal relationship in 'metro passengers have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed by locals' was not fully captured. Your version 'People on the metro see dogs often now. They are used to seeing them. So, locals do not often notice the dogs.' loses the strong degree of familiarity ('so used to') and the passive, almost invisible state ('largely unnoticed') of the dogs. Suggestion: Rephrase sentences to retain the original nuances. For example, for 'more likely', consider 'people give food to small dogs more than to big dogs'. For 'even learnt', consider adding a phrase like 'it is surprising that they learn'. For the last sentence, focus on conveying the strong degree of familiarity and the resulting lack of attention.

It is surprising. Some dogs learn to use the city's metro system. They go from one area to another area. Scientists do not know how dogs get off the train at the right time.
One idea is this: Dogs have a very, very good sense of smell. They learn to recognise the special smells of their favourite places. Another idea is this: Maybe they learn to recognise station names. They hear these names in train announcements.
People on the metro see dogs often now. They are very used to seeing them. So, locals do not notice the dogs.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6846 is below the required 0.75, indicating a significant loss of the original text's core message and nuance. This is an instant fail. The following points detail the specific deviations: The original text states dogs travel 'largely unnoticed'. Your version states 'locals do not notice the dogs', which implies complete lack of notice, losing the nuance of 'largely'. The original text uses 'Another possibility is that they have learnt'. Your version uses 'Another idea is this: Maybe they learn', which introduces a stronger degree of uncertainty than the original's more neutral 'possibility'. The original text implies surprise with 'Some dogs have even learnt'. Your version explicitly adds 'It is surprising', which is an interpretation and not a direct factual statement from the original, altering the objective tone. Suggestion: Ensure all nuances, even subtle ones like 'largely' or 'possibility', are preserved. Avoid adding interpretive statements like 'It is surprising' unless explicitly part of the original meaning. Rephrase sentences to maintain the exact degree of certainty or observation present in the source text.

Some dogs learn to use the city's metro system. They go from one area to another area. Scientists do not know how dogs get off the train at the right time.
One idea is this: Dogs have a very, very good sense of smell. They learn to recognise the special smells of their favourite places. Another idea is this: They learn to recognise station names. They hear these names in train announcements.
